tool.name: MethylIT: Goodness of Fit Report
tool.command: Rscript '$__tool_directory__/methylit_gof_report.R' --absolute '$absolute' --column $column --confl_model '$confl_model' --input '$input' --model '$model' --npoints $npoints --num_cores \${GALAXY_SLOTS:-4} --output_gof '$output_gof' --output_txt '$output_txt' --output_spec '$output_spec' --script_dir '$__tool_directory__' #if str($output_log_cond.output_log) == 'yes': &>'$output_log'; #else: &>output_log.txt; if [[ $? -ne 0 ]]; then cp output_log.txt '$output_data_frame'; cp output_log.txt '$output_grange'; fi #end if

param.name: input
param.label: Information divergence estimator file with information divergence values in the meta-columns

param.name: column
param.label: Index of the GRanges column where the information divergence is given

param.name: output_spec
param.label: Select output
param.help: --output: 'all' outputs the GoF statistics, the best fitted model and the corresponding statistics

param.name: confl_model
param.label: Return the best model based on highest R.Cross.val?

param.name: npoints
param.label: Number of points to be used in the fit
param.help: --npoints: Default is 0, which is tranlated to NULL

tool.help:
**What it does**
Searches for the best fitted model between the set of models requested by the user. Two goodness-of-fit (GoF) criteria are applied to select the best fitted model: Akaike's information criterion (AIC) and the correlation coefficient of cross-validations for the nonlinear regressions (R.Cross.val). These criteria evaluate different information inferred from the models. AIC deals with the trade-off between the goodness of fit of the model and the complexity of the model, while R.Cross.val provides information on the prediction power/performance of the model when confronted with external dataset.
Although the numerical algorithms to accomplish the nonlinear fit are not perfect, in general, the model with the lowest AIC must have the highest R.Cross.val. If the model with the lowest AIC has not the highest R.Cross.val, then further analyzes are required. These analyzes could include the visualization of the graphics for the density distribution, evaluation of whether the parameter values can be meaningful or not, etc. Nevertheless, the best model will, in general, lead to the identification of the greater amount of potential DMPs and DMPs, as well as, the highest classification accuracy estimated with functions. In the worse scenario, these observations can ultimately lead to a post-hoc decision on which the best model is.
